Xi Jinping:
Xi Jinping is a Chinese politician who has served as the General Secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC), President of the People's Republic of China, and Chairman of the Central Military Commission.  Considered one of the most powerful leaders in contemporary China, Xi has centralized institutional and personal power around himself, and his political thought has been incorporated into the party's and country's constitution, reflecting his influence on Chinese politics. 

Xi Jinping was born on June 15, 1953 in Beijing, into a family that was part of the political elite.  His father, Xi Zhongxun, was a veteran revolutionary and political leader who held several important positions in the government.  However, during the Cultural Revolution (1966-1976), his family fell out of favor and Xi Zhongxun was purged, while Xi Jinping was sent to the countryside to perform forced labor as part of Mao Zedong's reeducation policies. 

Xi Jinping joined the CPC in 1974 and studied chemical engineering at Tsinghua University, graduating in 1979.  He later obtained a doctorate in law and began his ascent in the party hierarchy by holding various positions in the provinces of Hebei, Fujian, Zhejiang, and Shanghai.  He earned a reputation for being an effective and unpretentious leader, with a strong ability to manage crises and promote economic development. 

In 2007, he was promoted to the CPC Politburo and later to the Politburo Standing Committee in 2008, signaling him as one of the future leaders of the country.  Eventually, he succeeded Hu Jintao as the General Secretary of the CPC in November 2012, as President of the People's Republic of China in March 2013, and as Chairman of the Central Military Commission, thus consolidating control over the most important branches of Chinese power. 

Since taking office, Xi Jinping has promoted a national rejuvenation agenda and advocated for what he calls the "Chinese dream", which includes revitalizing the CPC, strengthening state control over the economy and society, and asserting China on the world stage.  He has launched anti-corruption campaigns that have punished high officials and military personnel, reinforced censorship and internet control, and persecuted dissidents and activists. 

Internationally, Xi has promoted the "Belt and Road" initiative to expand China's economic and political influence, sought to reform global financial institutions, and adopted a more assertive stance in foreign affairs, particularly in the South China Sea and in relations with Taiwan and the United States. 

One of the most significant achievements of his regime was the abolishment of presidential term limits in 2018, which opened the door for him to remain in power indefinitely.  Xi's government has also been criticized for human rights violations, including repression in Hong Kong and policies in the Xinjiang region, which have strained relations with the international community. 

Under his leadership, China has experienced continuous economic growth, although it faces challenges such as an aging population, regional inequality, debt, and trade tensions with other economic powers.  Xi Jinping remains a central figure in China's evolution, and his policies and decisions will continue to influence the country's development and global power dynamics in the years to come.
Narendra Modi:
Narendra Modi is an Indian politician and the current Prime Minister of India, having assumed office since May 26, 2014.  He is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), which is part of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) political alliance, and has been a prominent figure in Indian politics for several decades. 

He was born on September 17, 1950, in Vadnagar, a small town in the state of Gujarat, to a family belonging to the Ghanchi caste.  From a young age, Modi showed interest in social work and became involved with the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist organization.  His commitment to the RSS eventually led him to join the BJP in 1987. 

Modi quickly rose through the ranks of the party due to his charisma and organizational skills.  He served as the BJP's general secretary in Gujarat and later in Haryana.  He stood out as a key figure in strengthening the party in Gujarat. 

In 2001, after the resignation of the then Chief Minister of Gujarat, Keshubhai Patel, Modi was elected to replace him.  He took effective measures to promote industrialization and economic development in the state, and his leadership helped improve infrastructure and attract foreign and domestic investments.  However, his tenure as Chief Minister of Gujarat was also marked by controversy, particularly in relation to the communal riots in Gujarat in 2002, which resulted in the death of numerous people, mainly from the Muslim community. 

Modi denied any responsibility and claimed that he did everything possible to control the situation.  However, his administration was criticized both nationally and internationally for its handling of the riots.  Despite the controversy, Modi was re-elected in 2002, 2007, and 2012 as Chief Minister of Gujarat, holding his position until 2014. 

During his years in the Gujarat government, he continued to implement policies to promote economic growth and modernization of the state.  His leadership and improvements in Gujarat's economy helped him forge an image as a figure of development and governance. 

In 2013, Narendra Modi was selected as the BJP's candidate for Prime Minister for the 2014 general elections in India.  Under his leadership, the BJP won a landslide victory, obtaining an absolute majority in the Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Indian Parliament.  Since taking office, Modi has initiated numerous economic reforms, including the implementation of a national goods and services tax (GST), the "Make in India" campaign to turn India into a global manufacturing hub, and the "Swachh Bharat" initiative to promote cleanliness and hygiene throughout the country. 

Modi has been praised for his focus on digital reforms, such as the "Digital India" initiative, and for his focus on expanding infrastructure and renewable energy.  In addition, his foreign policy has been proactive, seeking to strengthen ties with countries both regionally and globally. 

In 2019, Modi led the BJP to another electoral victory, consolidating his position as one of the most powerful leaders of contemporary India.  However, he remains a divisive figure, acclaimed by his supporters for his economic policies and criticized by his detractors in terms of handling freedom of expression, minority rights, and other social issues.
Joko Widodo:
Joko Widodo, commonly known as Jokowi, was born on June 21, 1961 in Surakarta, also known as Solo, in Central Java, Indonesia.  He is an Indonesian politician who has been the President of Indonesia since 2014.  Before becoming president, Jokowi served as mayor of Surakarta and governor of Jakarta, building a reputation as a practical and results-oriented leader, close to the concerns of the common people. 

Biography:

**Childhood and Education:**
Jokowi grew up in a humble family; his parents were wood sellers.  Despite economic difficulties, he managed to obtain a decent education, which allowed him to attend Gadjah Mada University in Yogyakarta, where he graduated with a bachelor's degree in forestry engineering in 1985. 

**Business Career:**
Before entering politics, Jokowi started his career in the private sector.  He worked in the wood industry and eventually became a successful entrepreneur in the furniture business.  His experience in commerce gave him a valuable understanding of the business world and a pragmatic approach to solving economic and management problems. 

**Political Career:**
Jokowi entered politics in 2005 when he was elected mayor of Surakarta, his hometown.  As mayor, he was recognized for his efforts to boost local economic development, improve infrastructure and public administration, and for his direct approach in dialogue with citizens.  His successful policies and leadership style gained national attention. 

In 2012, Jokowi made a significant leap in his political career by being elected governor of Jakarta.  In this role, he continued with his participatory management style and quickly gained public sympathy for his focus on improving public services, combating corruption, and reducing floods in the city. 

**Presidency:**
Jokowi's growing popularity led him to become the presidential candidate in 2014.  He won the presidential elections against Prabowo Subianto and was inaugurated as the 7th President of the Republic of Indonesia on October 20, 2014.  His election was seen as a milestone for Indonesian democracy, as he was the first president not to have a military background or belong to the Indonesian political or economic elite. 

During his first term, Jokowi focused on infrastructure development, bureaucracy reform, investment in the country's maritime sector, and improving health and education services.  His government has also been known for its focus on political and economic stability, and for adopting policies that promote foreign investment. 

In 2019, Jokowi was reelected for a second term after defeating Prabowo Subianto again.  He has continued to promote his development and reform agenda, although he has also faced criticism for human rights issues and his methods to strengthen national development sometimes at the expense of the environment. 

**Personal Life:**
Jokowi is married to Iriana Joko Widodo, and they have three children together.  He is known for his humility and his 'man of the people' approach.  Apart from politics, Jokowi has a well-known hobby for heavy metal music, being a fan of bands like Metallica and Megadeth. 

Jokowi's presidency has coincided with a period of significant transformation in Indonesia, a country with complex ethnic and religious diversity, and the largest economy in Southeast Asia.  His legacy will be defined by his ability to maintain national unity, promote economic growth, and improve the quality of life for the Indonesian population in a context of changing global and regional challenges.
Mamnoon Hussain:
Mamnoon Hussain was a Pakistani politician who served as the 12th President of Pakistan, holding office from September 2013 to September 2018. 

Born on December 23, 1940, in the Indian city of Agra, Mamnoon Hussain migrated with his family to Pakistan in 1949 after the partition of the Indian subcontinent.  They settled in Karachi, where Hussain was educated and later entered the business world. 

Hussain obtained his degree in commerce from the University of Karachi in 1963 and then ventured into the textile industry, where he developed his professional career.  His entry into political life was as a member of the Pakistan Muslim League (N) (PML-N), a major political party in Pakistan. 

Proving to be a loyal member of the PML-N, he held various positions within the party and also served in public administration roles.  He was appointed as the Governor of Sindh in 1999, but his tenure was brief due to the military coup that ousted Nawaz Sharif's government that same year. 

Over the years, Hussain remained active in politics and within his party, although he maintained a relatively low profile in national politics.  His election as President of Pakistan in 2013 was somewhat surprising, as he was not one of the country's most prominent politicians.  His candidacy for president was supported by the PML-N, which had won the general elections that year, and given Pakistan's parliamentary system where the president is elected by an electoral college consisting of members of Parliament and Provincial Assemblies, his election was secure due to the PML-N's majority. 

As president, Mamnoon Hussain had a mainly ceremonial role, as the Pakistani Constitution grants most executive power to the Prime Minister.  During his presidency, Hussain tried to promote national unity and economic development, although his influence on everyday politics and governance was limited. 

After completing his presidential term, Hussain left office in September 2018 and was succeeded by Arif Alvi.  His time as president was characterized by relative political stability and a discreet style in carrying out his functions. 

Mamnoon Hussain passed away on July 14, 2021, after a battle with cancer.  He was remembered by his colleagues and compatriots as a modest man dedicated to the service of his country.
Sheikh Hasina:
Sheikh Hasina, whose full name is Sheikh Hasina Wazed, is a prominent politician from Bangladesh known mainly for having held the position of Prime Minister on multiple occasions.  She was born on September 28, 1947 in Tungipara, which was then East Pakistan and is now Bangladesh.  She is the eldest daughter of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the first President of Bangladesh known as the "Father of the Nation" for leading the country to independence in 1971. 

Education and early years:
Sheikh Hasina attended the University of Dhaka, where she graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in Bengali language and literature.  During her youth, she witnessed the political turmoil that led to the independence war of Bangladesh from Pakistan. 

Early political career:
Her formal entry into politics was tragic: in 1975, her father and most of her family were assassinated in a military coup.  Hasina and her sister Rehana survived, as they were abroad at the time.  This event deeply marked Hasina and defined much of her future political life.  She stayed in exile in India, where she continued to be a prominent figure in Bangladeshi politics in exile until her return to Bangladesh in 1981. 

Leadership of the Awami League Party:
Upon her return, she assumed leadership of the Awami League Party, which was founded by her father.  She faced the military regime and worked to restore democracy in Bangladesh.  She was a staunch critic of military administrations and, due to her political activities, was arrested on several occasions. 

Prime Minister of Bangladesh:
Sheikh Hasina was first elected as Prime Minister of Bangladesh in 1996, a position she held until 2001.  During her tenure, she focused on education, health, and women's empowerment programs.  She also played a significant role in the signing of the Chittagong Hill Tracts Peace Treaty, which ended decades of conflict. 

After a period in opposition, due to an interim administration and the rival party, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), Hasina returned to power in 2009 and has been re-elected since then in 2014 and 2018, although these last elections have been criticized for alleged irregularities and lack of transparency. 

Achievements and controversies:
As Prime Minister, Sheikh Hasina has been praised for her leadership in economic growth and development in Bangladesh, including significant improvements in the country's infrastructure, poverty reduction, and achievements in gender parity in education.  However, her administration has faced criticism for alleged authoritarian practices, restrictions on press freedom, and human rights violations. 

Internationally, Sheikh Hasina has been recognized for her role in the Rohingya refugee crisis, in which Bangladesh has welcomed hundreds of thousands of displaced people from Myanmar.  On the other hand, she has been questioned on how her government has handled the human rights situation related to this crisis. 

Despite the challenges, Sheikh Hasina remains one of the most influential and important political figures in the contemporary history of Bangladesh, and her legacy is seen both in the substantial progress of her country and in the deep criticisms of her style of governance.
Shinzo Abe:
Shinzo Abe was a Japanese politician who served as Prime Minister of Japan on two non-consecutive occasions, first between 2006 and 2007 and later from December 2012 to September 2020.  As the leader of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), Abe was an influential figure in Japanese politics and was known for his reformist economic agenda, known as "Abenomics," as well as his stance on foreign and defense policy. 

Abe was born on September 21, 1954, in Tokyo, Japan, into a prominent political family.  His grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi, was Prime Minister of Japan, and his father, Shintaro Abe, was Minister of Foreign Affairs.  After graduating from Seikei University in Tokyo, Abe moved to the United States, where he studied political science at the University of Southern California. 

He began his political career in 1982, initially working for the Japanese government, and was later elected to the House of Representatives in 1993.  His political career progressed rapidly, holding various ministerial positions before becoming Secretary General of the LDP. 

In 2006, Abe succeeded Junichiro Koizumi as prime minister.  During his first term, which was relatively brief, he attempted to reform education and strengthen Japan's alliance with the United States, while also seeking a firmer stance on international affairs, including North Korea's nuclear program.  However, due to political scandals and health issues, Abe resigned in 2007. 

After a period out of the spotlight of politics, Abe made a strong comeback and was reelected as LDP president in 2012, which led him back to the position of prime minister in December of that year.  During his second term, he introduced "Abenomics," a mix of aggressive fiscal stimulus measures, monetary easing, and structural reforms aimed at revitalizing the Japanese economy struggling with deflation. 

In foreign policy, Abe sought to increase Japan's presence and influence on the world stage, advocating for a tougher line against North Korea and seeking a stronger relationship with Western allies, especially the United States.  He also pushed for a reinterpretation of Japan's pacifist constitution to allow for a greater role for the country's self-defense forces in global security operations. 

Abe left office on September 16, 2020, citing health problems, and was succeeded by Yoshihide Suga.  His time in office made him the prime minister with the longest non-consecutive service in Japan's history. 

Shinzo Abe died on July 8, 2022, after being attacked by a gunman while giving a speech in Nara, Japan.  His assassination shocked the country and the world, highlighting his political legacy and impact on contemporary Japanese politics.
Benigno Aquino III:
Benigno Simeon Cojuangco Aquino III, better known as "Noynoy" Aquino or simply PNoy, was a Filipino politician who served as the 15th President of the Philippines from June 30, 2010, to June 30, 2016.  Born on February 8, 1960, in Manila, he was the eldest son of Benigno Aquino Jr. , a prominent opposition leader during the martial law period under dictator Ferdinand Marcos, and Corazon Aquino, who became president of the Philippines after Marcos was ousted. 

Educated at the prestigious Ateneo de Manila University and the University of the Philippines, where he obtained a degree in Economics, Aquino began his career in the private sector before following in his parents' footsteps in politics.  He was largely motivated by the assassination of his father upon his return from exile in 1983, an event that galvanized popular resistance against Marcos and paved the way for the People Power Revolution in 1986 that installed his mother as president. 

Aquino served as a member of the House of Representatives for the second district of Tarlac from 1998 to 2007 and then as a senator from 2007 to 2010.  As a legislator, he was known for his simplicity and focus on transparency and anti-corruption issues. 

His presidency was marked by significant efforts in the areas of economic reform and good governance.  Policies were implemented to stimulate economic growth, improve foreign investment, and combat corruption.  He is credited with improving the country's macroeconomic conditions, resulting in higher credit ratings and steady economic growth.  He also embarked on a peace process with Muslim insurgents in southern Philippines and challenged China's claim in the South China Sea by bringing the case to the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague, where the Philippines won a favorable ruling in 2016. 

However, his administration also faced criticisms and controversies, such as inadequate responses to natural disasters and the Mamasapano massacre in 2015, where 44 members of an elite unit of the Philippine National Police were killed. 

After leaving the presidency in 2016, Aquino kept a relatively low profile in politics.  On June 24, 2021, Benigno Aquino III passed away at the age of 61 due to complications from a kidney disease.  His death marked the end of an era in Philippine politics, as he was a central figure in the country's contemporary political history, rooted in the legacy of two of the most influential democratic figures in the Philippines, his parents.
Tr\u01b0\u01a1ng T\u1ea5n Sang:
Trương Tấn Sang was an important politician in Vietnam who held the position of President of Vietnam from July 2011 to April 2016.  Born on January 21, 1949, in the province of Mỹ Tho, which is now part of Tiền Giang province, Trương Tấn Sang had a long career in the Communist Party of Vietnam (CPV), the country's single party. 

Early political career:
Trương Tấn Sang joined the CPV in November 1969 and took on various roles in communist youth organizations and local administration in southern Vietnam after the country's reunification in 1975.  During his rise in the party ranks, Sang gained a reputation as an efficient administrator and party cadre with a practical approach to problem-solving. 

Rise in the CPV and government roles:
Before becoming president, Trương Tấn Sang held numerous government and party positions.  He was a member of the CPV's Central Committee since 1991 and served in various leadership roles in both the government and the party apparatus, including positions as secretary in various CPV divisions and chairman of the People's Committee of Ho Chi Minh City. 

Presidency:
As head of state, although considered largely ceremonial as real power in Vietnam lies with the CPV General Secretary and the Prime Minister, Sang played a visible role in foreign policy and in promoting a progressive image of modern Vietnam.  He was also involved in overseeing the country's economic affairs, working on improving the investment climate to boost Vietnam's economic development and modernization. 

Policies and achievements:
During his tenure, Trương Tấn Sang pushed for economic restructuring and promoted Vietnam's international integration.  Vietnam continued to strengthen its diplomatic and trade relations with countries around the world, including signing several free trade agreements.  Additionally, efforts were focused on improving the legal system and infrastructure to attract more foreign investment. 

Retirement and later life:
Upon completing his presidential term in April 2016, Trương Tấn Sang retired from active politics.  His role in the government was closely followed by national and international press, leaving a legacy as one of the leaders who guided Vietnam through a period of economic changes and reforms. 

Currently, not much is known about Sang's life after his presidency due to the secretive nature of Vietnamese politics and local press.  Trương Tấn Sang's contributions and influence in Vietnam's political history are remembered for his efforts to modernize the economy and enhance Vietnam's stature on the world stage.
Recep Tayyip Erdo\u011fan:
Recep Tayyip Erdoğan is a Turkish politician who has played a central role in Turkish politics since the early 21st century.  He was born on February 26, 1954 in Kasımpaşa, a neighborhood in Istanbul, to a working-class family.  Erdoğan grew up in humble surroundings and his first political experience was during his years of study at Marmara University, where he graduated in Business Administration. 

His political career began in earnest with the Welfare Party (Refah Partisi), a Turkish Islamist party.  He was elected mayor of Istanbul in 1994.  As mayor, Erdoğan was praised for improving public services and addressing Istanbul's infrastructure and environmental issues.  However, in 1998, he was dismissed and imprisoned for four months for inciting religious hatred after reciting a poem that was interpreted as an incitement against Turkish secularism. 

Upon his release, Erdoğan adopted a more moderate and pragmatic approach.  He co-founded the Justice and Development Party (AKP) in 2001, notably distancing himself from his Islamist past and promoting a platform of "conservative democracy. " The AKP won the parliamentary elections the following year, and Erdoğan became Prime Minister of Turkey in 2003, after a law prohibiting him from holding public office was changed. 

As Prime Minister, Erdoğan oversaw a period of significant economic growth and reforms aimed at strengthening Turkey's democratic institutions and economy.  His government undertook reforms for future accession to the European Union.  However, during his terms, Erdoğan was also accused of authoritarianism and attempts to erode Turkish secularism and press freedom.  Concerns about the centralization of power in his hands increased, especially after attempts to crush the Gezi Park protests in 2013. 

In August 2014, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan was elected President of Turkey, and in April 2017, a referendum approved a series of constitutional amendments that abolished the position of Prime Minister and significantly expanded the powers of the president.  These changes came into effect after the 2018 elections, further consolidating Erdoğan as Turkey's dominant leader and blurring the lines between executive and legislative powers. 

Under Erdoğan's presidency, Turkey has continued to play an active role in regional affairs, including politics in Syria and relations with the European Union and the United States.  However, domestically, Erdoğan has continued to face criticism for repressing dissent, limiting press freedom, and the issue of human rights in Turkey remains a controversial topic.
Hassan Rouhani:
Hasan Rouhani is an Iranian cleric and politician who was born on November 12, 1948 in Sorkheh, near Semnan, Iran.  He is a member of the moderate clergy within the Iranian political spectrum and has held several important positions within the political system of the Islamic Republic of Iran.  Rouhani is also known for his more moderate and diplomatic stance compared to more conservative Iranian leaders, especially on international issues. 

Education and Early Career:
Rouhani began his religious studies at a young age in Semnan before moving to the holy city of Qom, where he studied theology.  Later, he studied law at the University of Tehran, where he obtained his bachelor's degree, and later a doctoral degree in constitutional law from the United Kingdom. 

Revolutionary Involvement and Political Positions:
During the years leading up to the 1979 Revolution in Iran, Rouhani was involved in the fight against the regime of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, supporting Ayatollah Khomeini.  After the victory of the Islamic Revolution, Rouhani took on various roles in the new administration, including in the Iranian Parliament, where he served for five consecutive terms from 1980 to 2000. 

He was the secretary of the Supreme National Security Council for a long time and played a key role in the country's defense and security policies.  During his tenure, he was one of Iran's main nuclear negotiators and played a role in handling controversies over Iran's nuclear program. 

Presidency:
In 2013, Rouhani was elected as the seventh president of Iran, succeeding Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.  During his campaign, he promised to improve Iran's foreign relations and address the country's economic situation by easing international sanctions.  His election was seen as a victory for the more moderate and reformist factions in Iran. 

The most notable achievement of his first term was the signing of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), commonly known as the Iran nuclear deal, in 2015.  This agreement was reached between Iran and the P5+1 (the five permanent members of the UN Security Council plus Germany) and promised a reduction in sanctions in exchange for restrictions on Iran's nuclear program. 

However, Rouhani's presidency was marked by significant challenges.  These included pressure from conservative factions in Iran, who criticized moderate and outward-looking policies, as well as the decision by US President Donald Trump in 2018 to withdraw the US from the nuclear deal and reimpose economic sanctions on Iran. 

In 2017, Rouhani was reelected for a second term.  Throughout his presidency, despite his efforts to improve Iran's economy and foreign relations, he faced an increasingly challenging international context and growing domestic discontent due to the difficult economic situation and political and social restrictions. 

Additional References:
Throughout his career, Rouhani has written several books and articles on a variety of topics, including law, politics, and religion.  Additionally, he has served as a member of the Assembly of Experts (the body responsible for overseeing and selecting Iran's Supreme Leader) and as president of the Center for Strategic Studies, among other academic and political positions. 

Finally, his presidency concluded in 2021 with the election of Ebrahim Raisi, a conservative cleric, as his successor.  Rouhani's presidency will be remembered for his attempts to navigate the complicated waters of Iranian politics and his relatively pragmatic approach to both domestic and international challenges.
Prayut Chan-o-cha:
Prayut Chan-o-cha is a retired Thai politician and general who has served as Prime Minister of Thailand since the 2014 coup d'état.  He was born on March 21, 1954 in the province of Nakhon Ratchasima, and graduated from the prestigious Royal Military Academy Chulachomklao. 

Military career:
Prayut began his military career in the infantry of the Thai army and progressively rose through the ranks.  He was commander of the 2nd Infantry Division, commander of the 1st Infantry Division, and later Chief of the Royal Thai Army.  During his ascent, Prayut earned a reputation for being a disciplined and strategic man. 

Coup d'état and government:
On May 22, 2014, as Chief of the Royal Thai Army, Prayut led a coup d'état after months of political crisis and protests against the government of Yingluck Shinawatra.  The coup ousted the elected government and Prayut became the leader of the Military Junta, formally known as the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO). 

Prayut was appointed Prime Minister in August 2014 by a national assembly appointed by the junta.  During his government, Prayut has focused his leadership on economic modernization and political reforms.  His administration has been criticized for the use of authoritarian measures, including the suppression of freedom of expression and the detention of political opponents. 

2019 Elections:
Under a new constitution designed during his administration, Thailand held general elections in March 2019, the first since the 2014 coup.  Although the election was controversial and irregularities were reported, the Palang Pracharath party, aligned with Prayut, managed to secure enough votes in parliament for him to continue as Prime Minister. 

Prayut's administration has been marked by the promise to restore stability to a nation that has experienced numerous coups in recent decades.  However, his leadership has continued to face significant challenges, including pro-democracy protests, concerns about human rights, and the management of the Thai economy.

Thein Sein:
Thein Sein is a Burmese politician who served as President of Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, from 2011 to 2016.  He was born on April 20, 1945 in the Ayeyarwady Region.  Before his career in civil administration, Thein Sein had a long career in the Myanmar military. 

In his youth, Thein Sein attended the prestigious Defence Services Academy (DSA) in Myanmar, where he trained as an army officer.  He rose through the ranks of the Burmese army to become a lieutenant general.  He also held various administrative and governmental positions.  He was deputy chief of defence services and secretary in the Ministry of Defence before becoming the First Secretary of the State Peace and Development Council (SPDC), the military-led governing body that took power in 1988 after a bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protests. 

Thein Sein was appointed Prime Minister in 2007, a position he held until 2011.  During his time as Prime Minister, he led a government that began to implement a series of reforms to open up the country after decades of isolation and authoritarian rule. 

His presidency, which began in March 2011 after the 2010 general elections, marked a period of transition for Myanmar.  Under his leadership, the country began a process of political and economic liberalization that included the release of political prisoners, such as the famous democracy activist and later country's leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, and the initiation of peace dialogues with various armed ethnic groups.  Additionally, Thein Sein worked to improve Myanmar's relationship with the international community, attracting foreign investment and development assistance. 

However, his government also faced significant criticism and challenges.  The reforms were seen by some as superficial or insufficient, and human rights issues, particularly concerning ethnic minorities like the Rohingya, continued to be a major concern.  The end of his term was also marked by the growing influence of Aung San Suu Kyi, whose party, the National League for Democracy (NLD), won a landslide majority in the 2015 parliamentary elections, although she herself could not become president due to constitutional restrictions. 

After his presidential term, Thein Sein retired from active politics.  His legacy is mixed, seen as an agent of change in some respects but also as part of an authoritarian regime with a problematic record on human rights and democracy.
Park Geun-hye:
Park Geun-hye is a South Korean politician who was born on February 2, 1952 in Daegu, South Korea.  She is known for being the first woman to serve as President of South Korea, holding office from February 2013 until March 2017 when she was impeached from her position following a corruption scandal. 

Park is the daughter of Park Chung-hee, who was President of South Korea from 1963 until his assassination in 1979, and Yuk Young-soo, the First Lady who was also assassinated five years earlier, in 1974.  Raised in a context of political turmoil, Park's early life was marked by these tragic events, which led her to assume the role of First Lady after her mother's death. 

After her father's death, Park briefly distanced herself from politics.  She studied electronic engineering at Sogang University and also obtained a Master's degree in women's studies at the University of Grenoble in France. 

Her political career began in earnest in 1998 when she was elected as a member of the National Assembly of South Korea for the Grand National Party, later known as Saenuri Party.  She was known for her strong stance on security issues and conservative economic approach.  Park was a popular legislator and held leadership positions within the party. 

Her first presidential candidacy was in 2007, although she was defeated in her party's primaries.  However, she persevered and was elected as the 18th President of South Korea in December 2012.  Her presidency focused on various initiatives, including economic reform and improving relations with North Korea. 

However, her tenure faced significant challenges and controversies.  The Sewol ferry tragedy in 2014, in which more than 300 people died, mostly high school students, raised questions about her leadership and her government's response capabilities. 

The scandal that led to her impeachment began in late 2016, when it was revealed that Choi Soon-sil, a confidante of Park, had exerted undue influence in government affairs and had used her relationship with the president to enrich herself.  This triggered massive public protests and led to a political impeachment process that culminated in her removal from office in March 2017. 

In 2018, Park Geun-hye was convicted of abuse of power, coercion, and bribery.  She was initially sentenced to a total of 24 years in prison, which was reduced to 22 years after appeals.  Her downfall from power has been one of the most dramatic episodes in recent South Korean politics and an example of how the links between political power and corporate interests can lead to corruption and abuse of power. 

It is important to note that details about her conviction and the length of her sentence may have changed subsequently, depending on the results of additional appeals or changes in South Korea's political situation.
Fuad Masum:
Muhammad Fuad Masum (in Arabic: محمد فؤاد معصوم) is an Iraqi politician and academic who served as the seventh President of Iraq from July 24, 2014, to October 2, 2018.  Born on January 1, 1938, in the city of Koya, in the Iraqi Kurdistan region, he is a member of a family known for its history of political activism. 

Education and academia:
Masum attended schools in his hometown before moving to Baghdad for higher studies.  He graduated from the Faculty of Law at the University of Baghdad in 1959 and later obtained a Ph. D.  in Islamic Law from Al-Azhar University in Egypt.  Upon his return to Iraq, Masum became a professor of Islamic law at the University of Basra in the early 1970s. 

Political career:
Masum's political career began in the 1960s when he joined the Kurdistan Democratic Party (PDK).  He faced political repression, exile, and life as a militant at various stages of his career, particularly under Saddam Hussein's regime. 

After Hussein's overthrow in 2003, he became a founding member of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) and played a key role in drafting the new Iraqi constitution.  He was elected to the National Assembly in 2004 and served as the first President of the Iraqi National Assembly in the post-Saddam era. 

Presidency:
On July 24, 2014, the Iraqi Parliament elected Masum as President, a largely ceremonial role in current Iraqi politics, which follows a parliamentary system.  His election reflected the political practice of power-sharing among the country's main ethnicities and sects, assigning the presidency to a Kurd, the prime minister position to a Shia, and the parliament speaker position to a Sunni. 

During his tenure, Masum worked amidst significant challenges for Iraq, including the emergence of the Islamic State (ISIS) that seized control of large areas of the country in 2014.  He sought to promote national unity and dialogue among Iraq's different communities and political factions.  He was also responsible for ratifying laws and representing Iraq in international relations. 

Masum left office in October 2018 and was succeeded by Barham Salih.  His presidency is remembered for facing one of the most tumultuous periods in modern Iraqi history, marked by sectarian conflicts and the fight against extremist groups.
Ashraf Ghani:
Ashraf Ghani, whose full name is Mohammad Ashraf Ghani Ahmadzai, is an Afghan politician, academic, and economist who served as the President of Afghanistan from September 2014 until August 2021.  Born on May 19, 1949 in Logar, Afghanistan, Ghani has a distinguished academic and professional background both in Afghanistan and internationally. 

Education and Academic Career:
Ghani attended Esteqial High School in Kabul before continuing his studies abroad.  He obtained his bachelor's degree in Anthropology from the American University in Beirut, Lebanon, in 1973.  He then moved to the United States to pursue a master's and a doctorate in Anthropology at Columbia University, which he completed in 1983. 

After earning his doctorate, Ghani joined the faculty of Johns Hopkins University as a professor of Anthropology and International Studies.  During this time, he also worked as an anthropologist for the World Bank, focusing on projects to improve economies in developing countries. 

Return to Afghanistan:
Following the fall of the Taliban regime in 2001, Ashraf Ghani returned to Afghanistan to contribute to the country's reconstruction process.  He played a significant role in the Loya Jirga, a grand traditional assembly used to establish a new government after the overthrow of the Taliban regime.  He later served as a UN advisor and as Minister of Finance in the Afghan interim government between 2002 and 2004.  In this role, he was instrumental in implementing economic reforms and promoting fiscal transparency and governance. 

Political Career:
Ghani ran for the presidency of Afghanistan for the first time in 2009, although he was unsuccessful.  He ran again in the 2014 elections and, after a prolonged and controversial electoral process that required an audit under international supervision, Ghani was declared the winner and succeeded Hamid Karzai as President. 

During his presidency, Ghani faced significant challenges, including the persistent threat of the Taliban, entrenched corruption, and the country's dependence on foreign aid.  He sought to implement reforms to modernize the economy, improve infrastructure, and strengthen Afghan security forces, while also pursuing peace with the Taliban through various rounds of negotiations. 

Fall of the Government:
In 2019, Ashraf Ghani was reelected in elections marked once again by fraud and controversy.  His second term was even more challenging.  The withdrawal of US and NATO troops from Afghanistan, announced by the Trump administration and continued by the Biden administration, left Ghani's government in a precarious position.  In August 2021, the Taliban swiftly took control of much of the country, culminating in the fall of Kabul. 

Ghani fled Afghanistan when the Taliban entered the capital, leading to criticism and accusations of abandoning the country at its most critical moment.  He later sought refuge in the United Arab Emirates.  The rapid fall of Kabul and Ghani's escape marked the collapse of the Afghan Islamic Republic government and the return to power of the Taliban after nearly two decades. 

Following his presidency, Ghani has faced criticism and scrutiny, both for his role in the fall of the Afghan government and for his management during his tenure.  His exact whereabouts and role after his presidency are not publicly known.
Salman of Saudi Arabia:
Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud is the current King of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, assuming the position on January 23, 2015, following the death of his half-brother, King Abdullah.  Born on December 31, 1935, he is the son of the founder of Saudi Arabia, King Abdulaziz Ibn Saud. 

Before becoming king, Salman held several important government positions.  He began his political career as the governor of the Riyadh province in 1954, when he was only 19 years old, and held that position for almost five decades until 2011.  His tenure as governor was characterized by a significant expansion and modernization of the capital, including infrastructure, education, and health services. 

In March 2013, he was appointed Minister of Defense, under which he oversaw the modernization and operations of the Saudi armed forces.  Additionally, Salman has been the head of the Economic and Development Council since 2014, where he played a key role in implementing broad economic reforms aimed at diversifying the Saudi economy beyond oil, known as Vision 2030. 

As king, Salman has continued to strengthen Saudi Arabia's strategic relations with other nations, including the United States and Middle Eastern countries.  He has also led the military coalition against Houthi rebels in Yemen, seeking to restore the internationally recognized Yemeni government.  However, this conflict has raised international concern due to the humanitarian consequences in Yemen. 

Internally, Salman's reign has seen a blend of conservatism and modernization.  He has enacted some social reforms, such as the historic decision in 2017 to allow women to drive.  His son, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, often credited with driving these reforms, is seen as the face of change in the kingdom, although he has also been criticized for his handling of human rights issues, including the repression of dissenters and the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. 

Despite international and local challenges, Salman has sought to present an image of leadership and stability.  As he ages, succession planning has become an increasingly relevant issue.  Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, due to his influence and official roles, is considered next in line for the throne, preparing to guide Saudi Arabia into the future.
Islam Karimov:
Islam Abduganiyevich Karimov was an Uzbek politician who served as the first President of Uzbekistan from the country's independence in 1991 until his death in 2016.  Born on January 30, 1938 in Samarkand, Uzbekistan, which was then part of the Soviet Union, Karimov was raised in an orphanage before being adopted. 

Karimov studied engineering and economics, starting his career in the aviation and machinery industry.  He progressively rose within the apparatus of the Communist Party of the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic, taking on several administrative and governmental positions.  In 1989, he was appointed First Secretary of the Communist Party of the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic, effectively becoming the leader of the republic. 

As the Soviet Union began to dismantle in the late 1980s and early 1990s, Karimov led the movement towards Uzbekistan's independence.  He became the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan on March 24, 1990, even before the country formally declared its independence from the Soviet Union on August 31, 1991. 

His government was marked by strong repression against political opposition and a limited free press, often criticized by international human rights organizations.  Karimov maintained a tight control over the country, promoting economic policies that, while aimed at post-Soviet stability, did not prevent issues such as corruption and a highly regulated economy dominated by the state. 

Under his leadership, Uzbekistan pursued a policy of neutrality and non-alignment, playing a strategic role in the region, especially after the September 11, 2001 attacks, when Uzbek air bases were used by US forces for operations in Afghanistan.  However, relations with the West were complicated, especially after the Andijan massacre in 2005, where Uzbek security forces violently repressed a protest, resulting in numerous deaths. 

Islam Karimov was reelected several times in elections whose integrity was questioned by international observers.  His government was known for its authoritarian approach and lack of transparency, and he personally was accused of human rights violations and suppression of dissent. 

Karimov died on September 2, 2016, after suffering a stroke.  He left a nation with a legacy of authoritarian stability and a set of socioeconomic and political challenges for his successor.  The news of his death generated political uncertainty in the region, given the lack of a clear successor in a country that had been shaped by his leadership for over 25 years.
Najib Razak:
Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak is a Malaysian politician who served as the sixth Prime Minister of Malaysia, holding office from April 2009 to May 2018.  Born on July 23, 1953, he is the son of Tun Abdul Razak Hussein, the second Prime Minister of Malaysia, and Rahah Noah.  Raised in a prominent political family, Najib was educated in Malaysia and the United Kingdom, where he studied at Malvern College and later graduated in economics from the University of Nottingham. 

Najib entered politics in 1976, at the age of 23, following the sudden death of his father, succeeding him as the youngest parliamentarian at that time.  He was quickly promoted within the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO) political party, which had dominated Malaysian politics since the country's independence in 1957. 

Before becoming Prime Minister, Najib held various ministerial positions in the governments of his predecessors, including the ministries of Energy, Telecommunications, and Education, as well as Minister of Defence and Minister of Finance.  His political career is notable for its continuous ascent and for having held a series of important ministerial portfolios. 

During his tenure as Prime Minister, he implemented some reforms to boost the economy and modernize the country with initiatives such as 1Malaysia and the Economic Transformation Programme (ETP).  However, his tenure was also plagued by controversies, including the 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) corruption scandal, which involved the alleged misappropriation of billions of dollars from a state development fund under his supervision. 

The 1MDB scandal had significant repercussions both within and outside of Malaysia, leading to investigations in several countries.  Questions about the integrity and transparency of Najib's government significantly contributed to the defeats of the UMNO party and the Barisan Nasional coalition in the 2018 general elections, led by the return to politics of former Prime Minister Dr.  Mahathir Mohamad. 

After losing power, Najib has faced multiple charges of corruption and money laundering related to the 1MDB scandal.  He has maintained his innocence and claimed that he was misled by financial advisors. 

Najib Razak's trial has been a historic event in Malaysia, as it marks the first time a former Prime Minister has been brought to justice for criminal charges.  In July 2020, he was sentenced to 12 years in prison and a fine of 210 million Malaysian ringgit (approximately 49 million US dollars) for his involvement in the 1MDB case.  Najib appealed the conviction and while his appeals were ongoing, he remained an active political figure and a Member of Parliament for Pekan, although his reputation and future in Malaysian politics have been significantly affected.
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi:
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi is a Yemeni politician who has served as President of Yemen since February 27, 2012.  Hadi assumed the presidency as part of an internationally backed political transition process that followed the country's protests during the Arab Spring and the subsequent resignation of then-president Ali Abdullah Saleh. 

Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi was born on September 1, 1945, in Thukain, a village in the Abyan governorate in southern Yemen.  He joined the army in 1970 and received military training both inside and outside of Yemen, including in Great Britain and Egypt.  Over the years, he rose in rank within the Yemeni armed forces. 

When South Yemen and North Yemen unified in 1990, Hadi played a key role in unifying the armies of the two previously divided nations.  He served as Yemen's Minister of Defense from 1994 to 1998 and as Vice President under the presidency of Ali Abdullah Saleh from 1994. 

During Saleh's tenure, Hadi maintained a relatively low profile.  However, his role became critical in 2011 when protests against Saleh rocked the country, part of a series of uprisings in the region known as the Arab Spring.  Following an attack on the presidential palace in June 2011, Saleh was injured and traveled to Saudi Arabia for treatment.  During his absence, Hadi temporarily assumed presidential responsibilities. 

The political situation led to the signing of a power transfer agreement in November 2011, in which Saleh agreed to transfer power to Hadi in exchange for immunity for himself and his family.  Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi was formally elected president in an election held in February 2012, where he was the only candidate, as part of the transition process designed to bring stability to the country.  His mandate was intended to be temporary, but several extensions and the growing instability in Yemen have kept Hadi in power. 

Hadi's government has faced enormous challenges.  The situation in Yemen was further complicated by escalating tensions between factions and the insurgency of the Houthis (a Shiite rebel movement) who took control of the capital, Sana'a, in 2014.  In 2015, Hadi was forced to flee to Saudi Arabia after Houthi rebels effectively took control of a large part of Yemen, including the capital. 

Since then, Yemen has been embroiled in a civil war with Hadi leading the internationally recognized government, based in Aden and later temporarily in exile in Saudi Arabia, but with much of the north and west of the country controlled by the Houthis.  The situation in Yemen has been further complicated by the intervention of a coalition led by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, which seeks to restore Hadi's government. 

Hadi's presidency has been marked by continuous efforts to regain control of Yemeni territories, and by criticisms of the management of the humanitarian crisis that the conflict has caused.  The war has had a devastating toll on the civilian population, creating one of the worst humanitarian crises in the world with millions of Yemenis depending on humanitarian aid to survive. 

This biography is based on information available until early 2023 and may not reflect more recent developments in the political situation in Yemen or the life of Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi.
Sushil Koirala:
Sushil Koirala was a Nepali politician who served as the 37th Prime Minister of Nepal.  He was born on August 12, 1939 in Biratnagar, Nepal, into a prominent political family; his uncle, Bishweshwar Prasad Koirala, was also a former Prime Minister of Nepal. 

As a member of the influential Koirala family, Sushil was active in politics from a young age.  He joined the Nepali Congress in 1954 and remained loyal to the party throughout his life.  His political career gained significant momentum in the 1990s, after the reintroduction of multi-party democracy in Nepal. 

During the phase of struggle for democracy in Nepal, Koirala was a vocal critic of the monarchy and an advocate for a democratic government.  He spent several years in prison and in exile due to his involvement in political movements against the monarchy. 

In 1991, Sushil Koirala was elected as a member of the House of Representatives (Pratinidhi Sabha) of Nepal, although his involvement in high-level politics would not take off until years later.  He was known for his simple life and his principled political beliefs. 

Within the Nepali Congress, he held various positions, including member of the Working Committee and the Central Working Committee.  Additionally, Sushil Koirala served as the Vice President of the party before being elected President of the Nepali Congress in 2010. 

His most prominent moment in politics came in February 2014, when he was appointed Prime Minister of Nepal.  His administration faced significant challenges, including the immensely difficult task of leading the country towards a new Constitution after years of deadlock and disagreements among the major political parties.  Ultimately, during his tenure, Nepal passed a new Constitution in September 2015, although it was met with controversies and protests from some ethnic minorities in the country. 

Sushil Koirala was known for his commitment to the principle of parliamentary democracy and his dedication to establishing a democratic republic in Nepal.  However, his tenure as Prime Minister was also marked by criticism related to the slow pace of reconstruction following the devastating 2015 earthquake that hit Nepal. 

Sushil Koirala lost the position of Prime Minister in October 2015 and died on February 9, 2016, at the age of 76, due to respiratory problems.  His death was a blow to Nepali politics, especially to his party, the Nepali Congress, where his leadership had provided a stabilizing influence.  His legacy includes efforts towards peace and rebuilding his country, as well as progress in Nepal's transition to a democratic federal state.
Vladimir Putin:
Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin was born on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad, now St.  Petersburg, in the former Soviet Union.  Son of Vladimir Spiridonovich Putin and Maria Ivanovna Shelomova, he grew up in a working-class family in a communal apartment.  He studied Law at Leningrad State University, where he also joined the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and graduated in 1975. 

After graduating, Putin joined the KGB, the Soviet security and intelligence agency, where he worked for 16 years.  His career in the KGB included an assignment in Dresden, East Germany, from 1985 until the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989.  After his service in the KGB, Putin retired with the rank of lieutenant colonel and returned to Leningrad. 

In 1990, he became an advisor to Anatoly Sobchak, rector of Leningrad University and soon the city's first democratically elected mayor.  Putin was promoted to the position of deputy mayor and was known for his tough stance against corruption. 

When Sobchak lost reelection in 1996, Putin moved to Moscow, where his political career advanced rapidly under the presidency of Boris Yeltsin.  He held various leadership positions before being appointed director of the Federal Security Service (FSB), successor to the KGB, in 1998, and later secretary of the Russian Security Council. 

In August 1999, Yeltsin unexpectedly announced that Putin would be his successor and appointed him prime minister.  A few months later, Yeltsin resigned, and Putin became the interim president of Russia on December 31, 1999.  He quickly won the presidential elections in March 2000. 

During his first term, Putin implemented economic and political reforms, and it was also during this time that he launched a second war against the separatist region of Chechnya.  His handling of the Chechen crisis contributed to his popularity in Russia.  He was reelected in 2004 with a large majority. 

In 2008, due to Russia's constitutional restrictions preventing more than two consecutive presidential terms, Putin could not run for a third term.  Therefore, he assumed the position of prime minister while his protege, Dmitry Medvedev, became president.  During this time, Putin remained the dominant figure in Russian politics. 

In 2012, Putin returned to the Kremlin for a third term as president after constitutional reforms extended the presidential term from four to six years.  He was reelected for a fourth term in 2018. 

Under Putin's presidency, Russia has experienced a resurgence in global political influence, along with internal consolidation of power.  However, his government has been repeatedly criticized both inside and outside Russia for the erosion of democratic rights and press freedom, the persecution of political opponents, and support for separatists in regional conflicts such as in Ukraine. 

Putin has been a central figure in major global events, including the annexation of Crimea in 2014, which led to international sanctions against Russia, and the military intervention in Syria in support of Bashar al-Assad.  His tenure has been characterized by rhetoric and policies that often challenge the post-Cold War Western order. 

Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 marked another critical point in his leadership, escalating international tensions and prompting condemnation and additional sanctions from the international community.  Putin has remained firm in the face of external pressure, maintaining a tight grip on power in Russia and exerting significant influence on global affairs.
Joachim Gauck:
Joachim Gauck is a German politician and Protestant pastor who served as the eleventh President of the Federal Republic of Germany.  He was born on January 24, 1940, in Rostock, which at that time was part of Nazi Germany and later found itself in the German Democratic Republic (GDR). 

Son of a ship captain who was arrested and sent to a Soviet gulag during the Stalinist era, Gauck grew up under the socialist dictatorship of the GDR.  He was academically trained in theology and became a Lutheran pastor, a profession that allowed him some independence from the atheist State of East Germany.  Through his work as a pastor, Gauck gained experience in supporting civil rights groups and dissent. 

As political tensions in the GDR began to escalate in the late 1980s, Gauck became more involved in politics.  He participated in the growing opposition to the communist regime and was one of the leaders of the church movement that played a significant role in the peaceful protests that ultimately led to the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989.  After German reunification in 1990, Gauck was elected to the first (and last) freely elected parliament of the GDR. 

With the reunification, Gauck became the Special Commissioner for the Stasi Archives, the feared secret police of the GDR.  In this role, he was responsible for overseeing the review and management of the millions of files that the Stasi had compiled on citizens over decades.  His work in defending transparency and fighting injustice earned him recognition and respect both in Germany and internationally. 

Joachim Gauck was not formally affiliated with any political party, which contributed to his public image as a non-political and conciliatory figure.  In 2012, after broad consensus among the major political parties, he was elected as the President of Germany.  During his term, which lasted until March 2017, Gauck stood out for his strong moral principles and advocated for freedom, democracy, and accountability for Germany's past, including both Nazism and the GDR dictatorship. 

Additionally, he became a respected public speaker and advocate for European integration, dialogue between cultures, and mutual understanding.  He decided not to run for a second term due to age reasons and was succeeded by Frank-Walter Steinmeier.  After his presidency, Gauck has continued to participate in public debates and serves as a respected elder statesman in Germany.
David Cameron:
David Cameron is a British politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 2010 to 2016.  Born on October 9, 1966 in London, England, David William Donald Cameron is the son of Ian Cameron, a stockbroker, and his wife Mary Fleur, a judge.  Coming from a privileged background, Cameron attended Heatherdown Preparatory School and then the prestigious Eton College.  He later studied Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) at Brasenose College, University of Oxford, graduating with first-class honors in 1988. 

After graduating, Cameron worked for the Conservative Party, initially as a researcher and later as an adviser to various ministers.  His career in politics included a period as Director of Corporate Communications for Carlton Communications before being elected as a Member of Parliament (MP) for the Witney constituency in Oxfordshire in 2001. 

His rise in politics was relatively swift; he was promoted within the party hierarchy and held various shadow positions, including leadership on education and employment matters.  In 2005, Cameron was elected leader of the Conservative Party, succeeding Michael Howard.  As leader, Cameron sought to modernize the party, promoting a more inclusive and centrist image, often compared to Tony Blair's "Third Way," and emphasizing policies related to climate change and corporate social responsibility. 

During his leadership, the Conservatives did not secure an absolute majority in the 2010 general elections, but Cameron became Prime Minister leading a coalition with the Liberal Democrats under Nick Clegg.  His time in office was marked by the implementation of austerity policies aimed at addressing the UK's budget deficit, as well as reforms to the welfare and education systems. 

Reelected in 2015 with an absolute parliamentary majority, Cameron continued his reform agenda but faced a significant challenge with the growing Euroscepticism within his party and the country.  In an attempt to resolve the division over the UK's membership in the European Union, Cameron called for a referendum on the country's EU membership, a promise he had made during the election campaign. 

The referendum, held on June 23, 2016, resulted in a victory for the "Brexit" campaign.  Although Cameron had advocated for remaining in the EU, he accepted the result and announced his resignation as Prime Minister.  He was succeeded by Theresa May, who assumed office with the task of leading the negotiations for the UK's exit from the EU. 

Cameron has also been criticized for his role in calling the referendum, which many saw as a failed attempt to appease the Eurosceptic faction of his party and resulted in significant political and economic change for the UK.  Since leaving office, he has been relatively removed from frontline politics and has worked on various projects, including setting up a charitable foundation and publishing his memoirs in 2019.
Fran\u00e7ois Hollande:
François Hollande is a French politician who served as the 24th President of France, holding office from May 2012 to May 2017.  Born on August 12, 1954 in Rouen, Normandy, Hollande studied at some of France's most prestigious educational institutions, including the HEC business school, the Paris Institute of Political Studies (Sciences Po), and the National School of Administration (ENA), the latter of which is known for training many of the country's top officials and politicians. 

Hollande began his political career as a special advisor for economic affairs in President François Mitterrand's cabinet in the 1980s.  He was later elected to Parliament in 1988, representing the Corrèze department until 1993 and again from 1997 to 2012. 

In 1997, Hollande was appointed National Secretary of the Socialist Party (PS), a position he held until 2008.  During this time, he gained a reputation as a moderate figure within the party and served as "First Secretary" from 1997 to 2008, leading the party during periods in both opposition and power. 

On a personal level, Hollande lived for a long time with Ségolène Royal, also a politician from the Socialist Party, with whom he had four children.  Royal was a candidate for the French presidency in 2007, but lost to Nicolas Sarkozy.  The relationship between Hollande and Royal ended in 2007. 

François Hollande was elected President of France in 2012, defeating the conservative incumbent Nicolas Sarkozy against the backdrop of the European economic crisis and public dissatisfaction with austerity policies.  During his tenure, Hollande focused his efforts on economic reforms, including measures to reduce France's budget deficit and address high unemployment.  He also supported legislation to legalize marriage and adoption for same-sex couples, a measure that became law in 2013. 

Hollande's presidency was also marked by challenges in foreign policy and security, including France's military intervention in Mali in 2013 to combat Islamic insurgent groups, and a series of terrorist attacks on French soil, the deadliest of which occurred on November 13, 2015 in Paris when several attackers killed 130 people and injured hundreds more. 

Despite his efforts, Hollande struggled with low approval ratings throughout much of his term due to the stagnant economy and persistent unemployment.  He decided not to run for reelection in 2017, becoming the first sitting French president not to seek a second term since the founding of the Fifth Republic in 1958. 

After leaving office, Hollande has remained active in public life and in the Socialist Party, and has written several books addressing his time in office as well as his vision of the political situation in France and Europe.
Sergio Mattarella:
Sergio Mattarella is an Italian politician, jurist, and academic who was born on July 23, 1941 in Palermo, Sicily.  He is mainly known for having been the 12th President of the Italian Republic, a position he assumed on February 3, 2015.  He comes from a family with a strong tradition in Italian political life; his father, Bernardo Mattarella, was a prominent Christian Democrat politician. 

Mattarella studied law at the Sapienza University of Rome, where he graduated with honors.  He then became a professor of Parliamentary Law at the University of Palermo, beginning his academic career before entering politics. 

His political career began in the 1980s when he was elected as a deputy in the Italian Chamber of Deputies for the Christian Democracy (DC), the dominant party in Italian post-war politics until the early 1990s.  During his time in parliament, Mattarella stood out for his integrity and commitment to legality, earning respect from all political sectors. 

In the 1980s and 1990s, he held several ministerial positions, including Minister for Relations with Parliament, Minister of Education, and Minister of Defense.  As Minister of Education, he played a significant role in the reform of the Italian educational system. 

After the dissolution of the Christian Democracy and the corruption investigations that shook the Italian political landscape in the operation known as "Clean Hands," Mattarella joined the Italian Popular Party, one of the successor parties of the DC. 

Sergio Mattarella also served as a judge on the Constitutional Court, appointed in 2011 by President Giorgio Napolitano, a role he held until his election as President of Italy. 

On January 31, 2015, he was elected as President of the Italian Republic following the resignation of Giorgio Napolitano.  As president, Mattarella has maintained an institutional and moderate profile, emphasizing the importance of national unity and European solidarity, especially during the European migration crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic. 

In addition to his role as head of state, he has had to mediate in several complicated coalition governments, using his experience and authority to promote political stability in Italy. 

A significant aspect of his presidency has been his emphasis on public morality and the fight against corruption, a legacy of his career as a legislator committed to these causes. 

Considered a calm but firm figure, Mattarella has managed to rise above partisan divisions and is respected across the Italian political spectrum.  His term as president was initially scheduled to end in 2022 but may be subject to changes depending on the political context and personal decisions. 

It should be noted that any information about events or developments related to Sergio Mattarella after the knowledge cut-off date may not be reflected in this biography.
Mariano Rajoy:
Mariano Rajoy Brey is a Spanish politician who was born on March 27, 1955 in Santiago de Compostela, La Coruña, Galicia.  A member of the People's Party (PP), Rajoy has held important public positions in Spain, including that of President of the Government, making him one of the most relevant leaders in Spanish politics in the early decades of the 21st century. 

Rajoy began his political career in his native Galicia.  He studied Law at the University of Santiago de Compostela and later joined the Corps of Registrars of Property in 1978, becoming the youngest registrar in Spain at that time. 

His political career started with his affiliation with Alianza Popular (AP), which later transformed into the People's Party (PP).  He was elected as a deputy in the Parliament of Galicia in 1981, initiating his rise in national politics from then on.  He held several positions in the regional administration before making the leap to national politics. 

Throughout the 80s and 90s, Rajoy held various ministerial positions.  During José María Aznar's governments, he was the Minister of Public Administrations, Minister of Education and Culture, and Minister of the Presidency.  He also took on the role of Minister of the Interior towards the end of Aznar's second term. 

In 2003, Aznar designated Rajoy as his successor at the helm of the People's Party.  He ran as a candidate for the presidency in the 2004 elections, which were marked by the terrorist attacks on March 11 in Madrid.  In a closely contested and emotional election, Rajoy lost to the socialist candidate, José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero.  Rajoy faced and lost against Zapatero again in the 2008 elections. 

However, in the 2011 elections, amidst a severe economic and financial crisis in Spain and Europe, Rajoy and the PP obtained a large absolute majority in the Congress of Deputies.  On December 21, 2011, Mariano Rajoy was sworn in as President of the Government of Spain. 

During his term, Rajoy implemented a series of austerity measures aimed at controlling the public deficit and addressing the economic recession.  These policies were controversial and led to numerous protests and social mobilizations.  His government also faced the challenge of the separatist movement in Catalonia, which culminated in an unauthorized referendum on the region's independence in October 2017 and the subsequent application of Article 155 of the Spanish Constitution, which temporarily suspended Catalan autonomy. 

Rajoy's term ended abruptly in June 2018 when he was ousted by a vote of no confidence after the National Court sentenced the People's Party for benefiting economically from the Gürtel corruption scheme.  Pedro Sánchez, leader of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), assumed the presidency following the motion. 

In June 2018, Rajoy announced his withdrawal from active politics and his intentions to return to his profession as a registrar of property.  Thus, he ended a long political career marked by his presence in numerous relevant positions and his efforts to handle Spain's complex economic, social, and territorial challenges. 

It is worth mentioning that this biography has focused on the most outstanding aspects of his political career up to the knowledge available until early 2023, and any subsequent events have not been included in this summary.
Petro Poroshenko:
Petro Oleksiyovych Poroshenko is a Ukrainian politician, businessman, and billionaire who served as the fifth President of Ukraine from June 7, 2014, to May 20, 2019.  Born on September 26, 1965, in Bolhrad, Ukraine, Poroshenko comes from a family with roots in the Vinnytsia region, in central-eastern Ukraine. 

Education and business career:
Poroshenko studied economics at Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv, graduating in 1989.  During his youth, he began his career in business management and managed to amass a considerable fortune through a series of businesses, including confectionery manufacturing.  His business empire also included the production of automobiles and televisions, among other ventures.  Poroshenko is commonly known for his chocolate brand "Roshen," from which he derived his nickname, "the Chocolate King. "

Political career:
Poroshenko's political career began in the 1990s.  He was elected to the Ukrainian parliament in 1998 and later held a series of government positions.  Due to his political history, he has been a member of different parties, reflecting the shifting loyalties and common political realignments in post-Soviet Ukrainian politics. 

After the Orange Revolution in Ukraine in 2004, Poroshenko held various important government positions, including serving as Minister of Foreign Affairs and Minister of Trade and Economic Development.  Poroshenko was a close ally of former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko, although they later had political differences. 

Presidency:
In 2014, following the Revolution of Dignity and the ousting of President Viktor Yanukovych, Poroshenko ran for the Ukrainian presidency, promising to restore order in a country torn by political turmoil and Russian aggression in Crimea and eastern Ukraine.  He won the presidential election with over 54% of the votes. 

During his presidency, Poroshenko worked to guide Ukraine towards greater integration with the West, seeking closer relations with the European Union and NATO.  He also led the nation while combating Russian influence and military actions, including the conflict in the eastern regions of Donetsk and Luhansk (known as the Donbass War). 

However, his presidency was marked by significant challenges, including accusations of corruption, slow implementation of promised reforms, and ongoing economic instability. Later, he moved to Finland where he studied at the University of Tampere, obtaining a master's degree in sanitation engineering.  Upon his return to Ethiopia, he worked in the academic field as an engineer and university professor. 

In terms of his political career, Hailemariam Desalegn began to gain prominence in Ethiopian politics in the 1990s, when he joined the Democratic Movement for the Unity of the Nations of the South political party, and later became part of the People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF), the ruling coalition.  He held various public positions before becoming Prime Minister, such as governor of the Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples Region (SNNPR) of Ethiopia and Minister of Foreign Affairs. 

Desalegn took over as Prime Minister after the death of Meles Zenawi, who had ruled Ethiopia for more than two decades.  As Prime Minister, Hailemariam Desalegn tried to continue his predecessor's policies, especially in economic development and poverty alleviation.  However, his tenure was marked by significant challenges, including political unrest, protests, and human rights violations, leading to criticism both domestically and internationally. 

During his tenure, Ethiopia continued to experience rapid economic growth, but also struggled with political repression, media censorship, and the detention of political dissidents.  Desalegn sought to implement reforms and even released thousands of political prisoners in an attempt to ease growing tensions. 

On February 15, 2018, in a surprising move, Hailemariam Desalegn announced his resignation as Prime Minister and EPRDF chairman, a decision seen as an opportunity to facilitate the political reforms promised by the government in response to widespread protests across the country.  His resignation paved the way for Abiy Ahmed to come to power, becoming the new leader of Ethiopia and subsequently introducing a series of high-profile liberal reforms. 

Hailemariam Desalegn is known for his moderate approach and efforts to maintain stability in Ethiopia during a turbulent period.  The impact of his brief but significant leadership in modern Ethiopian history continues to be the subject of analysis and debate.
Abdel Fattah el-Sisi:
Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is an Egyptian political and military leader who has been in power as president of Egypt since June 2014.  Born on November 19, 1954, in Cairo, el-Sisi comes from a middle-class family and joined the Egyptian armed forces at a young age. 

Military Career:
El-Sisi graduated from the Egyptian Military Academy in 1977 and rose through the ranks of the Egyptian army.  He also received additional military training in the United Kingdom and the United States, including an infantry training course at Fort Benning, Georgia, and a long-term course at the United States Army War College in Carlisle, Pennsylvania.
