His academic background includes a degree in Economics from the Catholic University of Santiago de Guayaquil, a master's degree in Economics from the Catholic University of Leuven in Belgium, and a PhD in Economics from the University of Illinois in the United States. 

Before entering active politics, Correa worked as a university professor in the Faculty of Economics at the San Francisco University of Quito.  He began his political career in the government of Alfredo Palacio, where he served as Minister of Economy and Finance in 2005. 

Correa was known for his leftist political stance and for being a staunch critic of neoliberalism and U. S.  influence in Latin America.  In 2006, he won the presidential elections with a campaign focused on proposals for change and political renewal, under the slogan of the "Citizen Revolution. " During his term, he promoted social welfare policies, investment in infrastructure and education, and greater state intervention in the economy. 

Internationally, he was one of the leaders of the Latin American integration movement and a co-founder of the Union of South American Nations (UNASUR).  He maintained close relations with other left-wing governments in the region, such as those of Hugo Chávez in Venezuela, Evo Morales in Bolivia, and the Kirchners in Argentina. 

In 2008, Correa convened a Constituent Assembly that resulted in the drafting of a new Constitution, which was approved by referendum.  The new Constitution granted more power to the state in the economy, recognized rights of nature, and sought to strengthen the democratic system and social policies. 

Reelected in 2009 under the new constitution and again in 2013, Correa enjoyed a high level of popularity thanks to a significant increase in social spending and a period of stability and economic growth driven by high oil prices, the country's main export. 

However, his administration was also criticized, mainly for his handling of press freedom and allegations of authoritarianism.  His relationship with the media was tense, often accusing private media of being part of a right-wing opposition seeking to destabilize his government. 

Correa decided not to run for reelection in 2017.  Lenín Moreno, who had been his vice president, won the presidential elections and took office promising to continue the policies of the Citizen Revolution, although he later distanced himself from his predecessor and began a process of approaching more conservative and business sectors. 

After his presidency, Correa has faced several legal problems in his home country.  In 2020, he was sentenced in absentia to eight years in prison for a bribery and corruption case known as the "Sobornos 2012-2016 case," which he denies and denounces as political persecution.  Since 2017, Correa has resided in Belgium, the home country of his wife.
Evo Morales:
Juan Evo Morales Ayma, commonly known as Evo Morales, was born on October 26, 1959 in Isallavi, a small town in the department of Oruro, Bolivia.  Of Aymara origin, Morales grew up in a family of subsistence farmers, which gave him an early awareness of the difficulties faced by indigenous people and peasants in Bolivia. 

In his youth, Morales devoted himself to coca cultivation and was an active defender of coca farmers in the Chapare, a region in the department of Cochabamba.  In the 1980s, he emerged as a prominent union leader, taking over the leadership of the coca growers' union.  His activism put him in opposition to the Bolivian government and to policies backed by the United States for eradicating coca crops as part of the war on drugs. 

Morales began his political career in the early 1990s, co-founding the Movement for Socialism (MAS) in 1997, a political party that represents the interests of coca farmers and other indigenous and marginalized communities.  He unsuccessfully ran for a seat in Congress in 1997, but was elected in 1998.  As a congressman, his focus on indigenous rights and his open criticism of neoliberal policies gained him recognition and support at the national level. 

In 2002, Morales conducted a surprising presidential campaign and, although he lost, his party consolidated as an important political force in Bolivia.  Finally, in 2005, Evo Morales won the presidential elections with more than 50% of the votes, becoming the first indigenous president of the country and marking a historic milestone. 

During his presidential terms, Morales implemented a series of political, economic, and social reforms aimed at reducing inequality and strengthening the economy through the nationalization of important industries such as gas and oil.  He also promoted the inclusion of indigenous peoples in government and carried out the enactment of a new constitution in 2009 that recognized Bolivia as a plurinational state. 

Morales was reelected in 2009 and again in 2014.  However, his term was tarnished by accusations of authoritarianism and discontent over his decision to seek a fourth presidential term despite a referendum in 2016 that rejected amending the constitution to remove term limits. 

The 2019 elections were engulfed in controversy due to allegations of electoral fraud.  After weeks of intense protests and after the armed forces suggested he resign, Morales resigned on November 10, 2019 and first went into exile in Mexico and then in Argentina. 

His departure from power led Bolivia into a period of political instability, which culminated in new elections in 2020, where the candidate of his party, Luis Arce, won the presidency, allowing MAS to regain control of the government.  Morales returned to Bolivia after an interim government was in power and the accusations against him were dropped. 

Evo Morales remains a polarizing figure in Bolivia and Latin American politics, and is recognized for both his achievements in reducing poverty and defending indigenous peoples, as well as his inclination towards a centralized style of government and his resistance to relinquishing power after his presidential terms.
Michel Martelly:
Michel Joseph Martelly, born on February 12, 1961 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, is a Haitian musician and politician who served as president of his country from May 14, 2011, to February 7, 2016.  Known for his charismatic stage presence and his compas/kompa musical style, Martelly was one of the most popular artists in Haiti before entering politics. 

Martelly grew up in a middle-class family in Port-au-Prince.  He became interested in music at a young age and received a formal education at a local Catholic school before traveling to the United States to further his studies.  However, music was his true passion, and in the 1980s, he began performing professionally. 

Before his political career, Martelly, popularly known as "Sweet Micky," was a prominent figure in Haiti's music scene.  He started his musical career in the nightclubs of Port-au-Prince and gained popularity for his extravagant and often controversial performing style.  Throughout the 80s and 90s, Sweet Micky became famous for his energetic performances and his ability to captivate the audience. 

In the political arena, Martelly entered the scene during a period of great instability for Haiti.  After the devastating 2010 earthquake that left the country in ruins, Haiti needed strong leadership.  Martelly ran for president and, despite having no prior political experience, managed to win the elections with a message of change and reconstruction. 

During his presidency, Martelly faced enormous challenges, such as managing the country's reconstruction after the earthquake, combating extreme poverty, and the need to improve the country's infrastructure and institutions.  His government had both accomplishments and criticisms; some saw him as a reformist and charismatic leader, while others accused him of authoritarianism and corruption. 

Martelly's tenure was also marked by a series of protests and political tensions, especially surrounding the parliamentary and presidential elections that were postponed several times, leading the country into a political crisis.  Despite some improvements in infrastructure and the promotion of tourism, his term ended without having resolved many of Haiti's endemic problems. 

After leaving the presidency, Martelly has remained relatively out of the political spotlight but continues to be a well-known figure in Haiti, both for his musical past and his presidential term.
Ra\u00fal Castro:
Raúl Modesto Castro Ruz was born on June 3, 1931 in Birán, in the current province of Holguín, Cuba.  He is the younger brother of Fidel Castro, with whom he shares a long and intertwined history in the Cuban revolution and politics. 

From a young age, Raúl was influenced by the political ideas of his older brother and became involved in the fight against the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista.  He was one of the participants in the failed assault on the Moncada Barracks in Santiago de Cuba on July 26, 1953, an event considered the beginning of the Cuban Revolution.  After this action, he was imprisoned but later released under an amnesty agreement. 

In 1956, Raúl was one of the 82 expeditionaries who traveled on the yacht Granma from Mexico to Cuba with the aim of overthrowing Batista.  He distinguished himself as an effective guerrilla commander in the Sierra Maestra and, by 1958, he commanded the Second Eastern Front "Frank País. "

After the triumph of the revolution in 1959, Raúl assumed important military and governmental roles.  Due to his military experience, he held the position of Minister of the Revolutionary Armed Forces (FAR) for nearly five decades, earning considerable respect within the military apparatus and allowing him to modernize and professionalize the Cuban armed forces.  Additionally, he played a fundamental role in the direction and planning of military operations abroad, such as in Angola and Ethiopia. 

In the political realm, Raúl was always seen as the right-hand man of his brother Fidel and an important member of the Communist Party of Cuba (PCC).  In 1965, he was appointed its Second Secretary and has also held various responsibilities in the Cuban state as Vice Prime Minister. 

With Fidel Castro's declining health, Raúl assumed the interim presidency of Cuba in 2006 and was officially appointed President of the Councils of State and Ministers in 2008.  During his presidency, he implemented a series of economic and social reforms aimed at updating the Cuban socialist model.  These included expanding the private sector, decentralizing state enterprise management, and encouraging foreign investment.  He was also responsible for a historic thaw in relations between Cuba and the United States, which culminated in the resumption of diplomatic relations between the two countries in 2015 and the visit of U. S.  President Barack Obama to Cuba in 2016. 

In April 2018, Raúl Castro stepped down from the presidency, paving the way for Miguel Díaz-Canel to succeed him.  However, he continued to exert influence in the party and Cuban politics as the First Secretary of the Communist Party of Cuba until April 2021, when he announced his retirement and was succeeded by Díaz-Canel in that position as well. 

Raúl Castro's health has been the subject of speculation in recent years.  Although he no longer holds top public positions, his legacy as a key figure of the Cuban Revolution and leader of the country for over a decade will continue to be studied and discussed by those analyzing the contemporary history of Cuba.
Danilo Medina:
Danilo Medina Sánchez is a Dominican politician who served as President of the Dominican Republic from August 16, 2012, to August 16, 2020.  His political career has been closely associated with the Dominican Liberation Party (PLD), a center-left political entity founded by Juan Bosch in 1973. 

Born on November 10, 1951, in Arroyo Cano, a small town in the province of San Juan, Medina comes from a humble family.  He completed his early studies in his hometown and obtained a bachelor's degree in economics from the Santo Domingo Institute of Technology (INTEC) in 1984.  During his university years, he became involved in politics and was active in student circles. 

Medina began his political career in the 1970s, while still a student.  He joined the PLD shortly after its foundation and quickly rose through the ranks of the party.  He was elected a member of the PLD's Central Committee in 1983 and later became part of the Political Committee, the party's most important decision-making body, in 1989. 

He has held various positions in the Dominican government throughout his career.  Between 1990 and 1994, Medina served as Director of the Planning and Development Office, the entity responsible for formulating the country's economic and social policies under President Joaquín Balaguer.  He also served as Technical Secretary of the Presidency (1996-1999) during President Leonel Fernández's term, playing a key role in the formulation and implementation of government policies. 

His first presidential bid was in 2000, but he was defeated by Hipólito Mejía.  In 2004, he supported Leonel Fernández's candidacy, who won the election.  Medina ran for president again in 2012 and this time emerged victorious.  During his administration, he promoted policies to improve the country's infrastructure, education, and health, including a controversial tax reform to finance these projects.  In 2016, he was reelected for a second term after promoting a constitutional reform that allowed consecutive presidential reelection. 

Medina's tenure was also marked by criticism and controversies, including accusations of corruption and authoritarianism.  Despite these criticisms, Medina left the presidency with high approval ratings, although his legacy remains a subject of debate within the Dominican Republic. 

Internationally, during his presidency, Medina worked on promoting the Dominican Republic abroad and strengthening ties with other countries, with a particular focus on Latin American and Caribbean integration. 

Since leaving office in 2020, Medina has remained active in politics, although he no longer holds a public office.  He continues to be an influential figure in the PLD and Dominican politics in general.
Juan Orlando Hern\u00e1ndez:
Juan Orlando Hernández, whose full name is Juan Orlando Hernández Alvarado, is a Honduran politician who was born on October 28, 1968 in Gracias, Lempira, Honduras.  He is known for having served as the president of Honduras for two consecutive terms, from January 27, 2014 to January 27, 2022. 

Hernández studied law at the National Autonomous University of Honduras and later obtained a master's degree in Public Administration from the State University of New York (SUNY) in Albany.  His political career began to take shape within the National Party of Honduras, one of the country's two main political parties. 

Before becoming president, Hernández held several important positions.  He was a congressman for Lempira in the National Congress since 1998 and became President of the National Congress between 2010 and 2013.  During his term, he promoted various reforms and laws, including some controversial ones such as the Public Finance Management, Exemptions Control and Anti-Evasion Measures Law in 2011, which aimed to improve the country's fiscal situation but was criticized by sectors that considered it contrary to the interests of the most vulnerable classes. 

In the 2013 presidential elections, Hernández won the presidency representing the National Party.  During his first term, he implemented tough policies against organized crime and gangs, which led to a significant reduction in the country's violence rates, although these policies were also criticized by human rights organizations due to accusations of abuses by security forces. 

His presidency was also tainted by corruption allegations, especially related to the diversion of funds from the Honduran Social Security Institute to his presidential campaign, a scandal known as the IHSS case.  Despite this, in 2017, he was reelected in controversial elections that were followed by allegations of electoral fraud and violent protests. 

Hernández's reelection marked a controversial moment in the country's political history, as the Honduran Constitution explicitly prohibits presidential reelection.  However, in 2015, the Supreme Court of Justice of Honduras eliminated the article that prevented presidential reelection, which allowed Hernández to run for a second term. 

During his second term, Hernández continued with security policies and promoted investment for economic development, but he faced significant challenges such as high emigration of Hondurans to the United States, often fleeing poverty and violence. 

In February 2023, Hernández was arrested in Honduras at the request of the United States on charges of drug trafficking and using firearms in drug trafficking activities.  He was later extradited to the U. S.  to face these charges in the American judicial system. 

Hernández's political career was marked by advances in the fight against crime, but also by strong political polarization, social discontent demonstrations, and allegations of corruption and authoritarianism.  His legacy remains a subject of debate and analysis in the context of Honduras's recent history.
Horacio Cartes:
Horacio Cartes is a Paraguayan businessman and politician who was born on July 5, 1956 in Asunción, Paraguay.  Coming from a wealthy family, Cartes became one of the most prominent businessmen in his country before entering the political arena. 

Business career:
From a young age, Horacio Cartes showed skills for business.  He entered the business world through the family business and over time diversified his interests in various sectors, including banking, agriculture, livestock, tobacco, and beverage production. 

Through his investments and companies, such as Banco Amambay and the tobacco company Tabesa, Cartes built a business conglomerate that granted him great economic influence in Paraguay.  His business success was also accompanied by controversies, including accusations of smuggling and money laundering, although he has consistently denied such claims. 

Political career:
In 2012, Horacio Cartes made a surprising turn in his career by announcing his intention to enter politics.  He joined the Colorado Party, one of the two traditional parties in Paraguay, and quickly positioned himself as a prominent figure within the party. 

In the 2013 presidential elections, Cartes ran as a candidate for the Colorado Party and won, assuming the presidency of Paraguay on August 15, 2013 for a five-year term.  His administration focused on promoting foreign investment, improving infrastructure, and boosting agriculture and livestock, two pillars of the Paraguayan economy. 

However, his government was not without criticisms and controversies, including accusations of nepotism, corruption, and the lack of significant progress in reducing poverty and inequality.  One of the most controversial episodes of his presidency occurred in 2017 when an attempt was made to push for a constitutional amendment that would allow presidential re-election, which ultimately did not succeed following intense protests. 

Legacy:
Horacio Cartes left the presidency in August 2018, being succeeded by Mario Abdo Benítez, also from the Colorado Party.  His legacy as president is mixed, with some recognizing his ability to attract investments and others criticizing his management for the outstanding issues in terms of transparency and social development. 

After his presidency, Cartes has continued to be an influential figure in Paraguayan politics, maintaining his power within his party and in the business landscape of his country.  In addition, he has had to face new investigations and accusations related to corruption and illicit activities, whose resolution is still ongoing. 

Given that the political landscape can change rapidly, it is possible that Horacio Cartes' reputation and influence in Paraguay may evolve in the years to come.
Daniel Ortega:
José Daniel Ortega Saavedra was born on November 11, 1945 in La Libertad, Chontales, Nicaragua.  He is known for being a prominent figure in Nicaraguan politics, especially as the leader of the Sandinista National Liberation Front (FSLN) and President of Nicaragua in various periods. 

Ortega was raised in a working-class family, and his youth was marked by political activism.  He joined the Sandinista National Liberation Front, a guerrilla group that opposed the dictatorship of the Somoza family, which had ruled Nicaragua for decades. 

During the 1960s and early 1970s, Ortega actively participated in the fight against the regime of Anastasio Somoza Debayle, leading to his imprisonment on several occasions.  After his final release in 1974, he went into exile in Cuba and returned to Nicaragua shortly before the Sandinista victory. 

In 1979, the FSLN managed to overthrow the dictator, and Ortega emerged as one of the members of the National Reconstruction Government Junta.  In 1984, Ortega was elected President of Nicaragua, leading the country during a period marked by the Sandinista Revolution, which involved profound social and economic reforms, as well as an armed conflict with the contras supported by the United States. 

His first presidency lasted until 1990, when Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated him in the elections, largely due to the wear caused by the civil war and the economic pressures imposed by the United States. 

After losing power, Ortega continued to lead the FSLN and remained a central figure in the Nicaraguan opposition.  He failed in his attempts to return to the presidency in the elections of 1990, 1996, and 2001. 

Finally, in 2006, Daniel Ortega was reelected president, and since then he has been reelected in successive elections, although these elections have been widely criticized by the international community for their lack of transparency and the suppression of the opposition.  He has been accused of authoritarianism and of establishing a regime characterized by political repression and human rights violations. 

During his subsequent terms, Ortega has been criticized for concentrating power in the hands of his family and allies, repressing protests and media, and amending the Constitution to abolish presidential term limits.  The political situation in Nicaragua has generated tensions and international condemnations, particularly after the 2018 protests against his government, which resulted in severe repression and numerous deaths. 

Despite this, Ortega has maintained significant support among certain sectors of the Nicaraguan population, especially for the social assistance programs and macroeconomic stability that his administration has promoted during certain periods of his government.
Tony Abbott:
Tony Abbott is an Australian politician born on November 4, 1957 in London, United Kingdom.  He is best known for having been the 28th Prime Minister of Australia, holding the position from September 18, 2013 to September 15, 2015.  Additionally, he has been the leader of the Liberal Party of Australia and a member of Parliament for the electoral district of Warringah in Sydney. 

Education and early life:
Although Abbott was born in the UK, he moved to Australia with his family when he was young.  He studied at the Catholic school St Aloysius' College in Sydney and then at St Patrick's Seminary, where he began studying to become a priest, although he later abandoned this path.  He continued his studies at the University of Sydney, where he obtained a Bachelor of Economics and a Bachelor of Laws.  Later, he won a Rhodes scholarship and completed a Master's degree in Politics and Philosophy at Queen's College, Oxford. 

Early political career:
After his studies, Abbott briefly worked as a journalist before entering politics as an advisor to Liberal Party leaders, including former Prime Minister John Howard.  He won a seat in the Australian House of Representatives in 1994 and his political influence grew. 

Abbott held several cabinet positions over the years, including Minister for Health and Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations.  He earned a reputation for being a conservative politician, with a particular focus on immigration policies and his opposition to same-sex marriage. 

Prime Minister of Australia:
In December 2009, Tony Abbott became the leader of the Liberal Party and led the opposition against Labor government under Kevin Rudd and later against Julia Gillard.  In the 2013 federal elections, Abbott led the Liberal Party and the Coalition (an alliance between the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia) to a decisive victory, thus becoming Prime Minister. 

During his time in office, Abbott implemented strong policies in various areas, including immigration with his "Stop the Boats" policy aimed at halting the flow of illegal immigrants arriving in Australia by boat.  He also advocated for the abolition of the carbon tax implemented by the previous government and promoted government debt reduction. 

However, Abbott faced leadership challenges and criticisms within and outside his party, particularly for his leadership style and specific policies.  He was ultimately replaced by Malcolm Turnbull in a leadership change within the Liberal Party in September 2015. 

Post-prime minister:
After his time as Prime Minister, Abbott remained an influential member of the Liberal Party until he lost his seat in Warringah in the May 2019 federal elections to independent candidate Zali Steggall. 

In addition to his political career, Abbott has been involved in various community service activities and continues to be a public figure in Australia, expressing his opinions on various issues through the media and conferences.
John Key:
John Phillip Key is a former New Zealand politician and businessman born on August 9, 1961 in Auckland, New Zealand.  He was the 38th Prime Minister of New Zealand, serving from November 2008 until his resignation in December 2016.  He is a member of the National Party, a center-right political organization in New Zealand. 

Key grew up in Auckland, raised by his mother in humble conditions after his father passed away when he was only six years old.  He proved to be a capable student and, after completing his education at Burnside High School and the University of Canterbury, where he obtained a Bachelor of Commerce, Key began his career in the banking and finance world.  He worked for companies such as Merrill Lynch in high-level positions, even being responsible for several of their operations in Singapore, London, and Sydney. 

Following his extensive career in the financial sector, Key returned to New Zealand and started his foray into politics, winning a seat in Parliament in 2002 as the representative for the Helensville electorate.  His political career rose swiftly, and after holding various significant positions in the National Party, including that of the Leader of the Opposition, Key led the party to an electoral victory in November 2008. 

As Prime Minister, Key was well-received for his ability to manage and navigate New Zealand through the global financial crisis and the 2011 Christchurch earthquake.  He implemented policies that promoted economic growth and development, including fiscal reforms, infrastructure improvements, and fostering innovation. 

John Key was known for his pragmatic style and for fostering relationships both with New Zealand's traditional allies, such as the United States and Australia, and with countries in the Asia-Pacific region.  He was also a staunch supporter of the free trade agreement known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a proposal aimed at enhancing trade relations among Pacific countries. 

During his tenure, Key faced various challenges, including demands for greater environmental protection and the rights of the indigenous Māori.  His government was criticized on occasions for decisions on issues like surveillance and natural resource management.  Despite controversies, Key enjoyed a high level of personal popularity for most of his time in office. 

In December 2016, to the surprise of many, John Key announced his decision to resign both as Prime Minister and leader of the National Party, stating that he wanted to spend more time with his family and believing it was the right time for new leadership for the country and the party.  He was succeeded by Bill English. 

Following his resignation, Key has been recognized for his services to the country, being appointed a Knight Grand Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit in 2017.  Moreover, he has returned to private life, taking on advisory roles and serving on the boards of several companies.  His legacy as Prime Minister is generally regarded as positive in terms of economic stability and leadership at national and international levels.
